title: 111_hr3330
content: The Act titled "Improved Oversight by Financial Inspectors General Act of 2009" amends the definition of material and nonmaterial losses to the Deposit Insurance Fund for the purpose of Inspector General reviews. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act is amended to define material loss as any estimated loss exceeding $200,000,000 after March 31, 2009. Additionally, reports on losses are required semiannually for non-material losses. The Inspector General of each Federal banking agency must identify losses incurred by the Deposit Insurance Fund every 6-month period, determine grounds for appointing the Corporation as receiver for non-material losses. The Inspector General of each Federal banking agency must identify losses incurred by the Deposit Insurance Fund every 6-month period and determine grounds for appointing the Corporation as receiver for non-material losses. The Inspector General will prepare a written report to the appropriate Federal banking agency and Congress on the results of their determinations, including the identity of any loss warranting an in-depth review and the reasons for such review. The Inspector General of each Federal banking agency must identify losses every 6-month period and provide a report on losses warranting an in-depth review within 90 days after the end of the period. The Inspector General of each Federal banking agency must identify losses every 6-month period and provide a report on losses warranting an in-depth review within 90 days after the end of the period. The report must be shared with any Member of Congress upon request. Additionally, a technical amendment changes the heading for subsection (k) of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act to "Reviews" and "Losses". Amendment to the definition of material and nonmaterial losses to the National Credit Union Share Insurance Fund for Inspector General reviews. Amendment to section 216 of the Federal Credit Union Act requires the inspector general to review the Administration's supervision of a credit union that incurs a material loss to the Share Insurance Fund. The report must identify reasons for the loss and provide recommendations to prevent future losses. The inspector general must provide a report on credit unions incurring material losses to the Share Insurance Fund, defining material loss as exceeding $25,000,000 plus 10% of the credit union's total assets at the time of assistance initiation. The report must be shared with the Comptroller General, the Corporation, State supervisors for State credit unions, and upon request, any Member of Congress. The Board must disclose a report upon request without omitting certain information, except for trade secrets, about the insured credit union or customer names. The Inspector General of the Board must report on losses incurred by the Fund for insured credit unions every 6 months, identifying material losses and appointing the Board as liquidating agent for non-material losses. The Inspector General of the Board reports on losses incurred by the Fund for insured credit unions every 6 months, appointing the Board as liquidating agent for any Federal or State credit union. A written report is prepared for the Congress on the results of the determinations, including identifying any loss warranting an in-depth review and reasons for such review. The Inspector General of the Board reports on losses incurred by the Fund for insured credit unions every 6 months, appointing the Board as liquidating agent for any Federal or State credit union. The report includes identifying losses warranting an in-depth review and providing a deadline for completion. The Inspector General must comply with the semiannual report requirements expeditiously, within 90 days after the end of the 6-month period covered by the report. The Comptroller General of the United States will review reports made by the Inspector General of the Board on losses incurred by the Fund for insured credit unions every 6 months. The Comptroller General will recommend improvements in the supervision of insured credit unions based on the review. The House of Representatives passed the document on July 29, 2009, with Lorraine C. Miller as the Clerk.
